title: @Riot: What are your thoughts on skillshot heals?
body:
Imagine we made a new support Champion who had a heal-on-ally ability that's basically a skillshot. Pretty much all ally heals are direct-target or, in Bard's case, something your ally can easily access. Same with shield-on-ally effects (Lux is an exception).

Would skillshot heals be an interesting way to create new gameplay, or would they just be frustration factories?

replies.body: Skillshot heals end up being stronger out of combat (where you can just have your ally stand still, which is effective but dull/annoying) than in combat (where they're a mixture of both interesting and frustrating as your ally dodges helpful effects unintentionally). Wouldn't do a straight skill shot heal as a result. A skillshot that, if it damaged an enemy champion, could then heal your allies in some way (e.g. missile that on enemy champ hit boomerangs back healing allies) by contrast might work, especially if the return speed was slow enough allies could react to it, putting themselves in its path.
Right, didn't ezreal W used to heal allies by the same AP ratio it damaged enemies?

It did. Making a skill where you get some benefit out of combat, more in combat, would also be a softer way of rewarding the more interesting, engaging use. I'd expect making the enemy engagement a requirement to be the most successful approach though, since it avoids the out of combat issues entirely.

In terms of why that was taken off Ezreal, that was before my time at Riot. My understanding though is that the primary reason behind the removal was just that Ezreal W did far too much at the time (damage, heal, enemy AS slow, allied AS boost).

I can't think of a way to elaborate on this well. Hopefully u get what im getting at here

I don't think a true skill shot heal would ever feel good, since as others have pointed out, your allies aren't trying to dodge you. It's confusing, and the worst case scenarios are really frustrating since (if you're anything like me) you'll occasionally uselessly dodge harmless ally skillshots out of reflex.

Maybe you could revisit the idea of positioning based healing from a different angle if you wanted to introduce a heal with innate counterplay. Just spitballin', but think of something like a reverse Fiddle Drain or a Karma tether which an opponent could body-block to interrupt might have some more satisfying gameplay. Even then, not so certain on the satisfaction player's side.  I don't think you'd want to primarily define a champion around such an ability, for example.

Bad idea. It'd be pretty much impossible to use in most team fights and there's already enough everyone needs to keep track of without worrying about having to dodge your own team's skillshots so the right person gets hit with the ability.

To what point or Purpose? Cause I can't see any good coming out of it, if a heal was made a skill shot for simply being a skill shot.

One interesting thought though, would be to give it a dual effect depending on whether it hit an ally or enemy. Those dual effects give the champ more options, while the ability remaining relatively balanced, since it be affected by the same mana cost and cooldown.

Same thing I was thinking, skill shot would be a stun if it hits a champion, but a heal if it hits an ally. 
Would need to be like {{champion:81}} skill shot that ignores minions, but unlike Ezreal, stops at the first champion hit.

Ezreal's W did actually heal allies in the initial form of the skill.

I believe what a Rioter said about it was that it was such a contradictory effect most of the time that it never felt satisfying to use.
That's one way to do it. Affects the first Champion struck, and applies an effect depending on whether it's ally or enemy.

I don't really like it. Your allies aren't trying to dodge your heal so there's no real point to making it into one. Support abilities that depend on your allies to make them work, like grabbing Thresh lantern, can be incredibly frustrating for the support when their allies don't properly use the abilities. I don't see a good reason to make an ability have that kind of frustration attached to it unless it's completely necessary for it.
Ya thats probably the entire most frustrating part of Lux's W as an example. I can't count the number of times allies have dashed away from my w only to blame me for "missing it".
